title: 109_s627
content: The "Investment in America Act of 2005" aims to make permanent a research and development credit to incentivize companies to increase research activities in the United States. This credit is crucial for creating quality jobs, better products, and higher productivity in the country. The "Investment in America Act of 2005" aims to make the research credit permanent by removing certain subsections from the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Additionally, there is an increase in rates of alternative incremental credit. These amendments apply to expenses incurred after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4 of the "Investment in America Act of 2005" increases rates of alternative incremental credit in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment applies to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. The "Investment in America Act of 2005" amends section 41 of the Internal Revenue Code to increase rates of alternative incremental credit. Taxpayers can elect for a 12 percent credit on qualified research expenses exceeding 50 percent of the average expenses of the previous 3 years. The "Investment in America Act of 2005" amends section 41 of the Internal Revenue Code to increase rates of alternative incremental credit. Taxpayers can elect for a 12 percent credit on qualified research expenses exceeding 50 percent of the average expenses of the previous 3 years. The credit under this paragraph shall be determined if the taxpayer has no qualified research expenses in any 1 of the 3 taxable years preceding the taxable year, with a credit rate of 6 percent of the qualified research expenses for the taxable year. An election under this paragraph applies to the taxable year for which made and all succeeding taxable years unless revoked. The "Investment in America Act of 2005" allows taxpayers to elect for a 12 percent credit on qualified research expenses exceeding 50 percent of the average expenses of the previous 3 years. This election applies to the taxable year for which it is made and all succeeding years unless revoked with the consent of the Secretary. Coordination with the election of the alternative incremental credit is also addressed in the Act. The amendments made by this section allow taxpayers to make an election for a 12 percent credit on qualified research expenses. The election can be revoked with the consent of the Secretary of the Treasury. Effective for taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act.
